values.title: create sdf description for urdf
Blank visual causes exception

content.raw:
Having a blank visual element causes Gazebo to throw an exception, e.g.:

    <?xml version="1.0"?>
    <sdf version="1.3">
      <model name="Polaris Ranger EV">
        <link name="rear_right_wheel">
          <!--pose>2.5313 -4.1567 7.2207 0.0 0.0 0.0</pose-->
          <pose>0.0 0.0 0.25 0.0 0.0 0.0</pose>
          <inertial>
            <mass>0.5</mass>
          </inertial>
          <visual name="visual">
          </visual>
          <collision name="collision">
            <geometry>
              <cylinder>
                <radius>0.11</radius>
                <length>0.5</length>
              </cylinder>
            </geometry>
            <surface>
              <friction>
                <ode>
                  <mu>100000.0</mu>
                  <mu2>100000.0</mu2>
                  <slip1>0.0</slip1>
                  <slip2>0.0</slip2>
                </ode>
              </friction>
            </surface>
          </collision>
        </link>
        <link name="chassis">
          <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
          <visual name="visual">
            <geometry>
              <mesh>
                <uri>model://polaris_ranger_ev/meshes/polaris.dae</uri>
              </mesh>
            </geometry>
          </visual>
        </link>
      </model>
    </sdf>

values.title: use of visual model instead of collision model for lidar sensors

content.raw:
Currently lidar sensors (or any ray sensor in general) use the physics engine for ray tracing. This results in proximity sensors perceiving a different world than optical sensors which is fine as long as those two are the same but once you start simplifying and abstracting models and worlds this becomes a very big problem. 

For example when you want to add grass or other vegetation as a perception obstructing element you could use just a visual model and no collision model, which would then allow proximity sensors to "cheat" and see through to the ground. Another example is the use of very simplified objects when the robot only has to interact with some part of it or not at all but still needs to be able to recognize the object.

Transparency of objects (alpha channel in the object's texture) should be considered as well - i.e. the beam should go through transparent/missing parts of the model in order to perceive the same shape as camera sensors.
content.html:
Currently lidar sensors (or any ray sensor in general) use the physics engine for ray tracing. This results in proximity sensors perceiving a different world than optical sensors which is fine as long as those two are the same but once you start simplifying and abstracting models and worlds this becomes a very big problem.

For example when you want to add grass or other vegetation as a perception obstructing element you could use just a visual model and no collision model, which would then allow proximity sensors to "cheat" and see through to the ground. Another example is the use of very simplified objects when the robot only has to interact with some part of it or not at all but still needs to be able to recognize the object.

Transparency of objects (alpha channel in the object's texture) should be considered as well - i.e. the beam should go through transparent/missing parts of the model in order to perceive the same shape as camera sensors.

values.title: Manipulating ContactPlugin Data

content.html:
Situation: Trying to write a plugin to determine exernal contact forces on a link and publish to a ROS msg.

Status: I have a custom SensorPlugin class written which takes the associated Contact sensor and I can access all the contact data from the gazebo msgs::Contacts. I've verified this some simple printfs.

Next Steps: I'd like to accumulate all external forces/torques and publish a single external force wrench in the link coord frame to a ROS msg. Publishing to Ros is fairly straightforward and there are a number of good code examples to go on. My current issue is with manipulating data coming from the sensor.

In my ContactPlugin load fn I grab a ptr to the physics::Link

this->world_ = physics::get_world(this->sensor_->GetWorldName());
physics::EntityPtr ent = this->world_->GetEntity(this->sensor_->GetParentName());
physics::Link * lnk = dynamic_cast<physics::Link*>(ent.get());
this->link_.reset(lnk);

In my update function I can grab current pose and contact data from sensor as follows:

msgs::Contacts contacts = this->sensor_->GetContacts();
math::Pose pose = this->link_->GetWorldPose();

First question: What cardinal point on my link does the pose correspond to, i.e. a point of (0,0,0) in the link frame would be where? At the cg or proximal at the output of the parent joint?

Second question: I could iterate through all contacts accumulating forces in the link frame

Vector3 tot_force;
Vector3 tot_moment;
for (int i = 0; i < contacts.contact_size(); ++i)
{
    //transorm force and moment to link frame
    tot_foce += new_force;
    tot_moment += new_moment;
}

However, this seems like something that would've already been done by your physics engine and I ought to be able to access the accumulated results. There are some force/torque accessors as members of physics::Link

Vector3 torque = this->link_->GetWorldForce();
Vector3 torque = this->link_->GetWorldTorque();

However, the results always seem to be zeros. Am I on the right track with this, is there an easier way?

Many thanks,

values.title: Allow contact sensor to reference multiple collision elements

content.raw: Currently a contact sensor returns contact information for a single collision element. Since some users may wish to approximate mesh-based collision elements with groups of simple shapes, it would be convenient to allow the contact sensor to report on multiple collision elements. This would streamline the process using contact sensors while switching between mesh-based collision elements and groups of simple shapes.
content.html: Currently a contact sensor returns contact information for a single collision element. Since some users may wish to approximate mesh-based collision elements with groups of simple shapes, it would be convenient to allow the contact sensor to report on multiple collision elements. This would streamline the process using contact sensors while switching between mesh-based collision elements and groups of simple shapes.

values.title: Add a Reset Event

content.raw:
Allows custom plugins to connect to reset events.

One example use case:  in [drcsim's vrc plugin](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/9a4d632a5f3f14633b89c1012c78f8490414ff1a/plugins/ros/VRCPlugin.cc?at=vrc_plugin), break pin joints if user resets model poses.

Also see:

 - issue #236 - race condition in sensor update.
 - issue #302 - signal when sim time advances.
content.html:
Allows custom plugins to connect to reset events.

One example use case: in drcsim's vrc plugin, break pin joints if user resets model poses.

Also see:

  • issue #236 - race condition in sensor update.
  • issue #302 - signal when sim time advances.

values.title: Sometimes when running Gazebo from the command line, two icons are brought up in the Launcher

content.raw: For systems using unity, at least, running the gazebo command from the command line may bring up two icons in the launcher (the ubuntu version of the dock). One is named "Gazebo: default" and other gets named "gazeb". This does not occur every time when running gazebo. It seems to happen to me pretty much every other time when running gazebo or gzclient from the command line. I have not been able to produce this bug when running gazebo directly from the launcher itself. It doesn't appear that gazebo is running any stray processes, so I'm not sure what's causing this.
content.html: For systems using unity, at least, running the gazebo command from the command line may bring up two icons in the launcher (the ubuntu version of the dock). One is named "Gazebo: default" and other gets named "gazeb". This does not occur every time when running gazebo. It seems to happen to me pretty much every other time when running gazebo or gzclient from the command line. I have not been able to produce this bug when running gazebo directly from the launcher itself. It doesn't appear that gazebo is running any stray processes, so I'm not sure what's causing this.

values.title: Check for rendering suppport in CMAKE testing generation

content.raw:
The goal is to be able to compile rendering needed tests only in those machines which already support them. Basically ones with direct rendering support.

Currently, there is a runtime check in gtest in this way:

```
#!c++

  if (rendering::RenderEngine::Instance()->GetRenderPathType() ==
      rendering::RenderEngine::NONE)
```

Since during cmake there is no chance of compiling and running an application we should find another way of asking the system about capabilities. Ideas:

1. Check glxinfo output and parse the relevant parts
2. Explore the Ogre code to see what is the previous C++ function currently doing. Relevant code is in: RenderSystems/GL/src/OgreGLRenderSystem.cpp
content.html:
The goal is to be able to compile rendering needed tests only in those machines which already support them. Basically ones with direct rendering support.

Currently, there is a runtime check in gtest in this way:

  if (rendering::RenderEngine::Instance()->GetRenderPathType() ==
      rendering::RenderEngine::NONE)

Since during cmake there is no chance of compiling and running an application we should find another way of asking the system about capabilities. Ideas:

  1. Check glxinfo output and parse the relevant parts
  2. Explore the Ogre code to see what is the previous C++ function currently doing. Relevant code is in: RenderSystems/GL/src/OgreGLRenderSystem.cpp

values.title: Factory test occasional seg-fault

content.raw:
I occasionally see a seg-fault in the factory test. Last night before I left I started a loop to run the factory test 200 times in gdb (build debug of course). It seg-faulted on try 67 on FactoryTest.Cylinder. I've attached a stack trace below. The top-most frame in our code was in gazebo::transport::Connection::Close at [line 400 of gazebo/transport/Connection.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/aef04df4d17338903066d2f35f794e22d15ab339/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc?at=default#cl-400).

content.html:
I occasionally see a seg-fault in the factory test. Last night before I left I started a loop to run the factory test 200 times in gdb (build debug of course). It seg-faulted on try 67 on FactoryTest.Cylinder. I've attached a stack trace below. The top-most frame in our code was in gazebo::transport::Connection::Close at line 400 of gazebo/transport/Connection.cc.

values.title: SDF Documentation: Pose definition is unclear

content.raw: There are many elements that require a <pose>. It has a type pose, but there is nothing in the sdf documentation that explains how it should be formatted. This is one example I found, but perhaps in the header there could be an explanation of what the types are.
content.html: There are many elements that require a <pose>. It has a type pose, but there is nothing in the sdf documentation that explains how it should be formatted. This is one example I found, but perhaps in the header there could be an explanation of what the types are.

values.title: Keyboard shortcuts don't work in fullscreen

content.raw:
The following keyboard shortcuts don't work while in fullscreen mode:

-Reset world (Ctrl+R)

-Reset model poses (Ctrl+Shift+R)

-Save (Ctrl+S)

-Save as (Ctrl+Shift+S)
content.html:
The following keyboard shortcuts don't work while in fullscreen mode:

-Reset world (Ctrl+R)

-Reset model poses (Ctrl+Shift+R)

-Save (Ctrl+S)

-Save as (Ctrl+Shift+S)

values.title: race condition, using uninitialized Scene::jointMsgs containing NaN's

content.raw:
starting pr2 simulation sometimes leads to this segfault:

~~~
(gdb) /home/hsu/projects/groovy/simulator_gazebo/gazebo/scripts/gui: line 2: 28902 Aborted                 (core dumped) `rospack find gazebo`/gazebo/bin/gzclient -g `rospack find gazebo`/lib/libgazebo_ros_paths_plugin.so
[gazebo_gui-3] process has died [pid 28899, exit code 134, cmd /home/hsu/projects/groovy/simulator_gazebo/gazebo/scripts/gui __name:=gazebo_gui __log:=/home/hsu/.ros/log/dc93b228-513e-11e2-944f-90e2ba191409/gazebo_gui-3.log].
log file: /home/hsu/.ros/log/dc93b228-513e-11e2-944f-90e2ba191409/gazebo_gui-3*.log
bt

#1  0x00007ffff4f71b8b in __GI_abort () at abort.c:91
#2  0x00007ffff4f670ee in __assert_fail_base (fmt=<optimized out>, 
    assertion=0x7fffee9a63f0 "!pos.isNaN() && \"Invalid vector supplied as parameter\"", 
    file=0x7fffee9a62b0 "/tmp/buildd/ros-groovy-visualization-common-1.8.4/debian/ros-groovy-visualization-common/opt/ros/groovy/stacks/visualization_common/ogre/build/ogre_src_v1-7-3/OgreMain/src/OgreNode.cpp", line=<optimized out>, function=<optimized out>)
    at assert.c:94

values.title: ServerFixture::Load(world, paused) has race condition

content.raw:
The ServerFixture::Load(world, paused) function (which is used for regression testing) returns before the world has been fully initialized. In 806ed4e, I've added a test to the [test_server_fixture_load_paused branch](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/test_server_fixture_load_paused..default) to illustrate the problem. On my machine, the world requires more than 100 ms but less than 1000 ms to initialize.

A pull request is in the works.

A pull request is in the works.

values.title: Right-click + drag zooms in and out

content.raw:
Instead of solely using the scroll wheel to zoom, it would be cool if you could zoom by holding the right mouse button and drag to zoom in and out. Drag up and you zoom out (as if you were pushing the scene away from you) and drag down and it zooms in (as if you were pulling the scene toward you). 

Then if you felt really into it, right and left could have the same function as left-click + drag. That way, holding the left mouse button moves you in the camera's yz plane and holding the right mouse button moves you in the camera's xy plane.
content.html:
Instead of solely using the scroll wheel to zoom, it would be cool if you could zoom by holding the right mouse button and drag to zoom in and out. Drag up and you zoom out (as if you were pushing the scene away from you) and drag down and it zooms in (as if you were pulling the scene toward you).

Then if you felt really into it, right and left could have the same function as left-click + drag. That way, holding the left mouse button moves you in the camera's yz plane and holding the right mouse button moves you in the camera's xy plane.

values.title: ability to specify "unassembled" model by adding joint offsets for both parent and child link

content.raw:
something like below ought to do it:

~~~
<joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
  <parent>
    <link>link1</link>
    <pose>0 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
  </parent>
  <child>
    <link>link2</link>
    <pose>0 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
  </child>
  ...
</joint>
~~~

By specifying pose offsets between parent link and the joint, as well as child link and the joint, allows for specification of links in an unassembled configuration.

values.title: Bullet compound shapes don't support all child shape types

content.raw:
Gazebo's interface to bullet defines a bullet compound shape and then attaches child shapes to that. We should be careful, because the bullet maintainer says that only certain shapes are intended to be supported with compound shapes. In particular, meshes and static planes are not supported. It seems to work fine, but this may be something to keep in mind.

http://code.google.com/p/bullet/issues/detail?id=348

values.title: Rotate user camera without translating camera

content.raw: It would be nice to be able to rotate the user camera without translating it. This would mean using the user camera's current position as the center of rotation. Perhaps holding shift while rotating the user camera could generate this behavior. This was discussed during pull request #212.

values.title: LaserScan causes gazebo to crash when moving around

content.raw:
This was originally asked on answers.ros.org [1], but upon more inspection I'm convinced this is a bug. 

Using the DRCSim Robot (I've tried versions 1.1,1.2, and 1.3, built both from source and the packaged versions) while using the "fake walking" and subscribing to the laser scan from the head, gazebo will crash. 

Steps for re-creating the bug: 

1. roslaunch atlas_utils drc_sim_v0.launch 
2. rosrun pr2_teleop teleop_pr2_keyboard cmd_vel:=atlas/cmd_vel 
3. rostopic hz scan 
4. Using the teleop_pr2_keyboard drive the robot around a bit. For me this will cause a crash in under a minute. This doesn't appear to happen when the robot is stationary. 

Here is a stack trace of what I get when gzserver crashes: http://pastebin.com/LYv3tt8t

I've filed this as a bug against gazebo rather than DRCSim because of the contents of the stack trace. 

[1] http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/591/drcsim-1213-with-gazebo-crashes-often-when-moving/

values.title: Header parsing fails when used inside the Fawkes Robot Software Framework

content.html:
During my diploma-thesis I used Gazebo with the Fawkes Robot Software Framework and encountered the problem that the message headers were parsed incorrectly and thus no connection could be established.

I fixed this problem for my work by adjusting the ParseHeader function of the Connection class so that the header get limited to the defined HEADER_LENGTH by changing the argument of the istringstream to a limited substring.

Old:

std::istringstream is(header);

New:

std::istringstream is(header.substr(0,HEADER_LENGTH));

I had no problems using Gazebo otherwise, the error only occured when using it with Fawkes.

values.title: ContactSensor::GetContacts() is not thread-safe

content.raw: When trying to use this function in another thread (in my case, it is in a ModelPlugin instead of a ContactPlugin), there seems to be a race condition when copying ContactSensor::contactsMsg. It usually dies due to an assertion when accessing indices and the size of the message has changed (i.e., accessing index 14 to copy and the size has changed to 4).

values.title: Saving world file does not include changes to Lights

content.raw:
Saving the world file in gzclient does not currently save any changes made to lights in the client program.

To test this:

1. Load an empty world (standard invocation of `gazebo`)
2. Add some spotlights or point sources
3. Move and/or rotate the sun (directional light)
4. Save world as `filename`
5. `grep '<light ' filename | wc -l` should be greater than 1 if you added any lights
6. `xmlstarlet sel -t -c '//light[@name="sun"]/pose' filename` should output something different than `<pose>0.000000 0.000000 10.000000 0.000000 0.000000 0.000000</pose>` if you moved or rotated the sun.
content.html:
Saving the world file in gzclient does not currently save any changes made to lights in the client program.

To test this:

  1. Load an empty world (standard invocation of gazebo)
  2. Add some spotlights or point sources
  3. Move and/or rotate the sun (directional light)
  4. Save world as filename
  5. grep '<light ' filename | wc -l should be greater than 1 if you added any lights
  6. xmlstarlet sel -t -c '//light[@name="sun"]/pose' filename should output something different than <pose>0.000000 0.000000 10.000000 0.000000 0.000000 0.000000</pose> if you moved or rotated the sun.

values.title: Gazebo crashes if a plugin parameter has an empty value

content.raw:
From [question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/599/gazebo-crashes-if-a-plugin-parameter-has-an-empty/)


...the plugin causes a segfault in gzserver as the `Element::GetValueString()` access the empty pointer returned by `Element::GetValue()`. Is there a special reason why `GetValueString()` and the other type specific getter functions do not return an empty string or the default constructed values if the parameter value is empty? Of course a simple workaround to circumvent the segfault would be to check if `GetValue()` returns a null pointer before calling `GetValueString()`.
content.html:
From question

...the plugin causes a segfault in gzserver as the Element::GetValueString() access the empty pointer returned by Element::GetValue(). Is there a special reason why GetValueString() and the other type specific getter functions do not return an empty string or the default constructed values if the parameter value is empty? Of course a simple workaround to circumvent the segfault would be to check if GetValue() returns a null pointer before calling GetValueString().

values.title: switch from pkg-config to find_package(), the cmake way

content.raw:
Motivation:  erroneous flags provided by catkin generated debs, e.g. `ros-groovy-urdfdom` install `/opt/ros/groovy/lib/pkgconfig/urdfdom.pc`, which contains a line
~~~
Libs: -L/opt/ros/groovy/lib -lurdfdom_model -lurdfdom_model_state -lurdfdom_sensor -lurdfdom_world /usr/lib/libboost_thread-mt.so -lpthread
~~~
that should be
~~~
Libs: -L/opt/ros/groovy/lib -lurdfdom_model -lurdfdom_model_state -lurdfdom_sensor urdfdom_world /usr/lib/libboost_thread-mt.so -lpthread
~~~
switching to `find_package()` will avoid this problem, but a separate fix to the `.pc` file should be applied as well.
content.html:
Motivation: erroneous flags provided by catkin generated debs, e.g. ros-groovy-urdfdom install /opt/ros/groovy/lib/pkgconfig/urdfdom.pc, which contains a line

Libs: -L/opt/ros/groovy/lib -lurdfdom_model -lurdfdom_model_state -lurdfdom_sensor -lurdfdom_world /usr/lib/libboost_thread-mt.so -lpthread

that should be

Libs: -L/opt/ros/groovy/lib -lurdfdom_model -lurdfdom_model_state -lurdfdom_sensor urdfdom_world /usr/lib/libboost_thread-mt.so -lpthread

switching to find_package() will avoid this problem, but a separate fix to the .pc file should be applied as well.

values.title: Lock features in a world

content.raw: When moving the robot or other movable objects around, sometimes I end up grabbing and accidentally moving 'fixed' objects that are part of an arena, or in some way meant to be permanent.  It would be a nice feature to have the ability to 'lock' certain features with an XML hook and a radio button in the GUI, such that those features could not be moved accidentally (or perhaps intentionally in an attempt to cheat during the VRC).  The features should still be selectable, so that properties could be viewed in the GUI, but they couldn't be moved if the 'locked' hook is set.

The features should still be selectable, so that properties could be viewed in the GUI, but they couldn't be moved if the 'locked' hook is set.

values.title: roll, pitch, yaw - set as radians pulled as degrees

content.raw: While using the gui (DRC Sim version 1.3) I can set the roll, pitch, yaw (RPY) pose values of a model in radians using the world tab on the left side of my display. If I deselect and reselect that model, the RPY values are converted to degrees where they once were radians. If other values are changed (such as x, y, z values), then the RPY values are automatically pulled in as input, but they are read in as radians causing further rotation.

values.title: SetForce/SetTorque in class ODELink / Point of application of forces and torques

content.raw:
I posted this issue a while ago in the old Trac system on code.ros.org (see [here](https://code.ros.org/trac/ros-pkg/ticket/5573)). As there was no reaction until now and it does not only affect the simulator_gazebo package for ROS, I repost it here:

> I am using the released version 1.6.16 of ros-fuerte-simulator-gazebo.

> The [gazebo_ros_force](https://code.ros.org/svn/ros-pkg/stacks/simulator_gazebo/trunk/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_force.cpp) plugin calls the SetForce() and SetTorque() methods to apply a wrench to a given link in Gazebo, which is forwarded to dBodySetForce/dBodySetTorque in [ODELink.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d50d145f8639646720c5c1738bc74b0645614e18/gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.cc?at=default#cl-376). According to the ODE API documentation the method dBodySetForce is "mostly useful to zero the force and torque for deactivated bodies before they are reactivated". I wonder if the lines should be replaced by AddForce()/AddTorque() or AddRelativeForce()/AddRelativeTorque(), what seems to be much more useful to me. Additionally, the result of SetForce/SetTorque calls is totally undetermined unless the exact plugin execution order is known.
> 
> The following related problem affects Gazebo itself, not only the gazebo_plugins package. Perhaps I should rather report it on Bitbucket?
> 
> I stumbled accross the fact, that ODE's dBodyAddForce/dBodyAddRelForce functions apply the force at the body's center of gravity, not at its origin, which led to a faulty simulation of aerodynamic drag and propulsion in our  [hector_quadrotor_controller](http://ros.org/wiki/hector_quadrotor_controller) package (see [http://ode-wiki.org/wiki/index.php?title=HOWTO_damping#Aerodynamic_Drag](http://ode-wiki.org/wiki/index.php?title=HOWTO_damping#Aerodynamic_Drag) for reference). IMHO this should be documented more clearly in the API documentation, because its not what I would have expected. Additionally, I think AddForce() is used incorrectly in the VehiclePlugin that comes with Gazebo in this case.

Note that dBodyAddForceAtRelPos() also adds forces relative to the center of mass, too, not relative to the origin of the body.
content.html:
I posted this issue a while ago in the old Trac system on code.ros.org (see here). As there was no reaction until now and it does not only affect the simulator_gazebo package for ROS, I repost it here:

I am using the released version 1.6.16 of ros-fuerte-simulator-gazebo.

The gazebo_ros_force plugin calls the SetForce() and SetTorque() methods to apply a wrench to a given link in Gazebo, which is forwarded to dBodySetForce/dBodySetTorque in ODELink.cc. According to the ODE API documentation the method dBodySetForce is "mostly useful to zero the force and torque for deactivated bodies before they are reactivated". I wonder if the lines should be replaced by AddForce()/AddTorque() or AddRelativeForce()/AddRelativeTorque(), what seems to be much more useful to me. Additionally, the result of SetForce/SetTorque calls is totally undetermined unless the exact plugin execution order is known.

The following related problem affects Gazebo itself, not only the gazebo_plugins package. Perhaps I should rather report it on Bitbucket?

I stumbled accross the fact, that ODE's dBodyAddForce/dBodyAddRelForce functions apply the force at the body's center of gravity, not at its origin, which led to a faulty simulation of aerodynamic drag and propulsion in our hector_quadrotor_controller package (see http://ode-wiki.org/wiki/index.php?title=HOWTO_damping#Aerodynamic_Drag for reference). IMHO this should be documented more clearly in the API documentation, because its not what I would have expected. Additionally, I think AddForce() is used incorrectly in the VehiclePlugin that comes with Gazebo in this case.

Note that dBodyAddForceAtRelPos() also adds forces relative to the center of mass, too, not relative to the origin of the body.

values.title: Building Editor: Fix door/window movement behavior

content.raw:
When a wall has a door/window, and the wall length is decreased so that it can no longer accomodate the door/window, the door/window moves with the wall as it shrinks, but does not return to its original position once the wall length is increased again. Instead, the door/window remains at the far end of the wall where it moved to when the wall length was decreased.

This seems to only happen when the wall is resized from the start point of the wall, not the end point.

values.title: Laser View: wrong measurements and visualization

content.raw:
The range readings shown by the laser viewer seems to either have some constant offset or some bug in how it obtains distances in general. For example for the 30m hokuyo it show's a max range of 30.1m even though it's 30.0m (verified by reading out the actual sensor values with `gztopic echo`). 
You can also measure angles that do not actually exist ... I have not verified whether the angles inside the workspace are all valid but you are able to get angles that are outside the workspace (see attached image).

When looking at the visualization for the 10m hokuyo in the gazebo database which has a 260 degree field of view (which btw is wrong if this laser is supposed to replicate a Hokuyo URG-04LX) you can also see that something is wrong with how the laser scan and measurements are displayed. As you can see in the attached image circle 1 seems to be the center of the drawn scan while circle 2 is the assumed center used for drawing measurements (circle 3 can be ignored I guess as you're not considering the offset of optical center to base).

(this is both in default and laser_vis_fix)
content.html:
The range readings shown by the laser viewer seems to either have some constant offset or some bug in how it obtains distances in general. For example for the 30m hokuyo it show's a max range of 30.1m even though it's 30.0m (verified by reading out the actual sensor values with gztopic echo). You can also measure angles that do not actually exist ... I have not verified whether the angles inside the workspace are all valid but you are able to get angles that are outside the workspace (see attached image).

When looking at the visualization for the 10m hokuyo in the gazebo database which has a 260 degree field of view (which btw is wrong if this laser is supposed to replicate a Hokuyo URG-04LX) you can also see that something is wrong with how the laser scan and measurements are displayed. As you can see in the attached image circle 1 seems to be the center of the drawn scan while circle 2 is the assumed center used for drawing measurements (circle 3 can be ignored I guess as you're not considering the offset of optical center to base).

(this is both in default and laser_vis_fix)

values.title: is_static has no effect

content.raw: setting the is_static flag to true inside the gazebo interface does not make the model static.
content.html: setting the is_static flag to true inside the gazebo interface does not make the model static.

values.title: orbit view focal point ray-tracing ignores object when inside bounding-box

content.raw: When the camera is inside the bounding box of an object (e.g. driver's seat of the polaris ranger) then the model seems to be ignored when ray-tracing the position for the orbit viewer's focal point. This then causes the point to be set somewhere far outside the object which makes it more difficult to navigate inside the model.

values.title: Atlas position control performance inconsistant across machines

content.raw:
I recently observed a significant difference in performance running the Atlas position control plugin on two different machines. On one machine, the robot stands stably at the zero position. On the other, the robot has a qualitatively different response and falls over immediately.

The setup on both machines is identical (and both are using drcsim 1.3.1 and gazebo 1.3.1). The only discernible difference between the machines are the speed at which the simulation runs---something that should not affect a controller running on simulation time.

Attached are the PID gains used in this test. 

Thanks.
content.html:
I recently observed a significant difference in performance running the Atlas position control plugin on two different machines. On one machine, the robot stands stably at the zero position. On the other, the robot has a qualitatively different response and falls over immediately.

The setup on both machines is identical (and both are using drcsim 1.3.1 and gazebo 1.3.1). The only discernible difference between the machines are the speed at which the simulation runs---something that should not affect a controller running on simulation time.

Attached are the PID gains used in this test.

Thanks.

values.title: Building Editor:: Improve Inspector placement

content.raw:
When an Inspector opens, it should open close to where the user clicked to open it (but outside of the building bounding box). 

If more than one Inspector is opened, they should not overlap so much that the bottom ones are hidden from view.
content.html:
